052CACA2018841F7B22DF8F6D3762042.description: build a small stair unit with a temporary handrail.

9171E94833DE444482F3718925AAB924.description: lay out and cut stringers, risers, and treads; and

5A59E5C0CD7446309E535AFC6A8EFFE3.description:
calculate the total rise, number and size of risers, and the number and size of treads
required for a given stairway;

BE3D6047B1DC49498042867F7ED2E238.description: identify the materials used in the construction of stairs;

F90CA74FFC654B0BB00A0FBBC2122BF7.description: identify the various parts of stairs;

DA007E9F8F9846319418D35D8E8E19FA.description: identify the various types of stairs;

17054E8A29F34B3698D499090035B11A.description:
The student is introduced to various types of stairs and the common building code requirements
related to stairs. The student is expected to:

A0D1F10A12A54B118BECCC909CFBA574.description:
identify and explain the use and installation of various door and window hardware,
including security hinges, keepers, deadbolts, and peep holes.

857A971D704E4A58B399BA6701FE1DE8.description: identify the various types of locksets used on exterior doors and explain how the locksets are installed;

4C716507E5CD4D899734AD045E2A3998.description: identify types of thresholds used with exterior doors;

2F26F52DACAA4DD2A8C163B592E66160.description: identify the parts of a door installation;

1FB0EBF8EECC4844BA71A1332CD45FAD.description: identify the common types of exterior doors and explain how they are constructed;

21D20D1C4ECD448D8F062B4632498AD1.description: state the requirements for proper window installation;

8C019C62226E42C1A7B8CC10D4DB7BD9.description: identify the parts of a window installation;

B835A8A056754AABA1B42AB1841F43DA.description: identify various types of fixed, sliding, and swinging windows;

FDB3667838DB4854A53AEB1804A304E9.description:
The student gains knowledge of various types of windows, skylights, and exterior doors. The
student is expected to:

668A3640ABD1426A9BFC12695FC040D6.description: erect, plumb, and brace a simple concrete form with reinforcement.

EA26B9F0460043E6BFBC0D844861B67B.description:
explain the safety procedures associated with the construction and use of concrete forms;
and

5AD2A42DD73A461FA4E2A35A0D817561.description: identify the parts of various types of concrete forms;

8F022DE606F14E5CBE0CD31B7EB9BD69.description: identify various types of footings and explain their uses;

C609D7842A9E42ADBF5477D5D7C8F9E7.description: identify types of concrete reinforcement materials and describe their uses;

212B8539511A4487983453E584DCC5CB.description:
The student knows the ingredients of concrete, various types of concrete, and methods to mix
concrete. The student is expected to:

E36A480D77AC4184B12703167CFFA7DE.description: estimate the materials used for framing and sheathing a roof.

DFDE157028A64858BA2FF29951B4D92E.description: erect a gable roof using trusses;

66CBFBC7F9494F23A1DFC69F1144DA78.description: frame a gable roof with vent openings;

C3B60F3331B84DF2B458233F11B7CC49.description: identify various types of sheathing used in roof construction;

3AA6427C7CED4823BE24A86783611AEA.description: use a framing square, speed square, and calculator in laying out a roof;

2CEAF44D112D431585884E72C111BB06.description: identify the various types of trusses used in roof framing;

34BB43BDC7304C7FA44AB71E18755751.description: identify the methods used to calculate the length of a rafter;

AF1110FE5BDA46D08AAB20D47F8EEDFA.description: identify the roof framing members used in gable and hip roofs;

6B853EE24526412D9FDE5C8D10D326FC.description: demonstrate an understanding of the terms associated with roof framing;

39C733C952CB42D582A19887EA0DFB17.description:
The student gains knowledge of various types of framed roofs and how to frame these roofs using
both stick-build and truss-build systems. The student is expected to:

B48D0A5E61F14010984BEACB48DD6735.description: estimate the materials required for frame walls and ceilings.

C5DA35C824BD466EA9F21664D83D2FE5.description: cut and install ceiling joists on a wood frame building; and

7CF092507A2140C2A657F964B984E56A.description: explain the use of metal studs in wall framing;

A966DD83FB864C4BB488E81FE651C71F.description: describe wall framing techniques used in masonry construction;

296F0939781E45D5AEA9F4911ADDC43C.description: lay out, assemble, erect, and brace exterior walls for a frame building;

93DF8C888B8B4F029DD39C0030B0D755.description: identify the common materials and methods used for installing sheathing on walls;

4A9576A8A26B415BACAE70E45C7A5BB5.description: describe the correct procedure for assembling and erecting an exterior wall;

671F7BA2B3364F05A5EE505705020139.description:
describe the procedure for laying out a wood frame wall, including the installation of
plates, corner posts, door and window openings, partition Ts, bracings, and firestops;

16F2CDED42A7462385A545CC03A92060.description: identify the components of a wall and ceiling layout;

D7865BBC8A85439A83E14BFFF2DF912D.description:
The student knows how to lay out and frame walls and ceilings, rough-in door and window
openings, construct corners and partition Ts, brace walls and ceilings, and apply sheathing. The
student is expected to:

BF40656DA3CF416CB9580DB82B969A4C.description:
install a single floor system using tongue-and-groove (T&G) plywood or oriented strand
board (OSB) panels.

8D2ED7772BF14F53996826ED276633B8.description: install a subfloor using butt-joint plywood or oriented strand board panels; and

12A1A4E965F148A29168D657A27FA63B.description: lay out and construct a floor assembly;

B9F086B8B2F84476AB6F9C2843CF3CCB.description: estimate the amount of material needed to frame a floor assembly;

0DD9733FFCDE4CED9241C20D5BE2F223.description: select the appropriate fasteners to be used in various floor framing systems;

FB9848FA70FD4CBAA23ECC190B33EBF0.description: explain the purposes of subflooring and underlayment;

7DE8859B7B5B4C94A0FE79DEAEE043E1.description: list and recognize different types of flooring materials;

43EC2D14AB2543EFB2B5F5F427B35A2D.description: list and recognize different types of bridging;

07CC83CC5A8845C6A432614908B9FB30.description:
select the proper girder or beam size from a list of available girders or beams given
specific floor load and span data;

B76EF68A12C946E7B731A220D98F60C2.description: name the methods used to fasten sills to the foundation;

B52C70F9A7624374B35FDB2031274605.description: identify floor and sill framing and support members;

90741F96C6034603A8C208E71593E0E3.description: read and interpret drawings and specifications to determine floor system requirements;

75D85DAEF14241FE8F1832AA289C170E.description: identify the different types of framing systems;

5AE699EDA3334533B3B8E0461723E0A3.description:
The student gains knowledge of wood framing and the layout and construction of wood-framed
floor systems using common and engineered lumber. The student is expected to:

6FB56CB01D874A35803BBB97889723D4.description: demonstrate or describe how to perform a quantity takeoff for materials.

E7747D7BC86B4A47BF4F791C057573A0.description: identify and describe the parts of a specification; and

EBCB22F477F5440F9536626F87AB623C.description: state the purpose of written specifications;

A0E611DDA1D64B32AD6699EB7BCA2E7D.description:
read and interpret plans, elevations, schedules, sections, and details contained in basic
construction drawings;

4E0C4C2899CA470E996AF15AF9FDB9E8.description: identify selected abbreviations commonly used on plans;

2F8A53B13F7B4EECBFF8D3FBD7C3087C.description: identify selected electrical, mechanical, and plumbing symbols commonly used on plans;

83AE1ED8E67B40D6BB2AB64CAA4CBD63.description: identify selected architectural symbols commonly used to represent materials on plans;

9909E08D44A94322BA5158CEEE3DD706.description: identify the different types of lines used on construction drawings;

CA40A5A7CCD246A8A42AAE3B6A498E2E.description:
describe the types of drawings usually included in a set of plans and list the information
found on each type;

09203F83B74947E1B77FCB8239EB6936.description:
The student interprets architectural and engineering working drawings and specifications. The
student is expected to:

DE64C6295B234AB4BF2BE9926258D866.description: use portable power tools in a safe and appropriate manner

9CE3BE4E2BB6447A9EA83A14BB5FB7D1.description:
identify the portable power tools commonly used by carpenters and describe their uses;
and

213257479A584237915D5BFD3FB5D761.description: state the general safety rules for operating all power tools, regardless of type;

BF091B22BC9949CDBD9494F0307F62AD.description: use hand tools in a safe and appropriate manner;

4F38962ED8944F3D9A0DF284B2473FE0.description: identify the hand tools commonly used by carpenters and describe their uses;

1814D6387C4C4441A40B7935EA6124D4.description:
The student applies the proper and safe use of hand and power tools associated with carpentry.
The student is expected to:

47B85CAB4FAF4B3CB17E9D4EFFD245A8.description:
describe the fasteners, anchors, and adhesives used in construction work and explain their
uses.

3C5E945E736744A2AA651CB49362D1DA.description:
calculate the quantities of lumber and wood products using industry-standard methods;
and

455F69AED4CB4920A6928B1FFEA94536.description: state the uses of various types of engineered lumber;

C82B62326A6641D7BCDC25FC620D16D9.description: describe the proper method of storing and handling building materials;

ED2514DEBD56431D99D2260644AE9572.description: identify the different grades and markings of wood building materials;

B7FA6E270BD64354AE40C1AEF8192DA7.description: state the uses of various types of hardwoods and softwoods;

8CC40255E83B4347A34DBE20BC46A6E4.description: identify various types of building materials and their uses;

172FA947CF4F45DE9E6E139A09A24E3C.description:
The student gains knowledge about building materials used in the construction industry. The
student is expected to:

1E1A010C736442D29E95324C955F6AF3.description:
research careers along with the education, job skills, and experience required to achieve
them.

4CAD80F8E8F94FF3B7D26EFDEB2445ED.description:
identify job opportunities and their accompanying job duties such as carpentry, building
maintenance supervisor, architect, and engineer; and

9547F8DEFB974B119A517CD473E26DAF.description:
The student identifies various opportunities in the field of carpentry and the characteristics a
carpenter should possess. The student is expected to:

F0F041E0B6014C45A315E46ED36F92BF.description:
demonstrate the use and care of appropriate personal protective equipment, including
safety goggles and glasses, hard hat, gloves, safety harness, and safety shoes.

7C7BFFA873724398ABDAF263D94FAE4E.description: define safe work procedures around electrical hazards;

80B87251EC814CD094589645A6C14607.description: explain the importance of Safety Data Sheets (SDS);

671EB72D604B43018EE6C082DAAB6853.description: explain the importance of hazard communication (HazCom);

850AB6A89BB2480EA3A4A7E4EDED4C29.description: explain fall protection, ladder safety, stair safety, and scaffold safety procedures;

3393E986A0724AA4969A92DB781DEF4F.description:
explain the role of Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) in job-site
safety;

9A7D7420AF1C4D44A648DE1597CA3388.description: explain the importance of a safety culture in the construction crafts;

D2D3637C26384A9783D5AAAFE6F2E172.description: explain the idea of a safety culture;

ACAD9D98C9744244AA556E4BE0E49EA1.description:
The student understands that safe working standards are imperative in the classroom and in the
field. The student is expected to:

EA4390EC20A04753840AC735EA722F8E.description: recognize workplace issues such as sexual harassment, stress, and substance abuse.

0789E3C93FCF48779D452970FBC8F40A.description: explain common uses for computers in the construction industry;

CB4EEEBFD51747898898E59902586319.description: demonstrate knowledge of basic computer systems;

B11A8C2A6F0C456F88D13166E82CB157.description: demonstrate the ability to solve problems using critical-thinking skills;

1E5215C3C6AC47D29412A86D72FDB19B.description: explain the role of an employee in the construction industry;

3B1FC12E0D7F4FEC9CA3183B90E9E02A.description:
The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and
industry. The student is expected to:

B0A003C5EC2F4D1EAC6F1791E48ACF63.description:
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those
containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

8FAB0AA010C6491995097AD907491103.description:
Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and
technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

1A6AC8907A664F7B890C77F713FD1226.description:
In Construction Technology I, students will gain knowledge and skills needed to enter the
workforce as carpenters or building maintenance supervisors or to prepare for a postsecondary
degree in construction management, architecture, or engineering. Students will acquire knowledge
and skills in safety, tool usage, building materials, codes, and framing. For safety and liability
considerations, limiting course enrollment to 15 students is recommended.

FDD279A1BD244ED89182081DD43D3F96.description:
The Architecture and Construction Career Cluster focuses on designing, planning, managing,
building, and maintaining the built environment.

525DFACED60D42028AF56E5E38AC20A1.description:
Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic
standards and relevant technical knowledge and skills for students to further their education and
succeed in current or emerging professions.

BDDCD671B6414986A6DF55B177292570.description:
General requirements. This course is recommended for students in Grades 10-12. Recommended
prerequisite: Principles of Construction or Principles of Architecture. Students shall be awarded two credits
for successful completion of this course.
